Award.AwardTitle: US - Korea Joint Workshop on Collaboration in Software Defined Networking/Network Function Virtualization (SDN/NFV) for Smart Cities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project funds a workshop that brings together researchers from the US and Korea, for the purpose of describing and assessing the impact of advanced networking on the engineering of smart cities. Researchers who specialize in programmable networking, including SDN (software defined networking) and NFV (network function virtualization) will work with leading researchers interested in the broad areas of smart cities, including enabling technologies such as large-scale sensor and actuator deployment (wireless and wired) and the Internet of Things (IoT) as applied to the smart city application domain. Research in smart cities has a clear benefit to society, in improving the lives of people through the use of technology, including in the domains of energy efficiency and health-care delivery. However, techniques for how to structure secure, reliable, and flexible networked communications in support of smart cities is poorly understood. The workshop will explore and document key technology challenges and opportunities that arise when next generation networking and smart cities are considered together.

The workshop will be held August 16-17, 2014, in Chicago, Illinois. Potential US participants will be invited to submit one-page abstracts of their interest and ideas in the workshop areas. These abstracts will be reviewed by the US workshop organizers, and approximately 20 participants will be selected. This proposal supports travel expenses for the US participants only; Korean participants are being selected and funded by their national agencies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There was consensus among the workshop participants that SDN/NVF for smart cities using the IoT was an important are of research for the good of society in both the US and Korea. There are many hard research problems, and significant synergies between Korean and US researchers that would benefit from a joint research program.

Architecture: SDN (software-defined networking), NFV (network function virtualization), and the IoT (Internet of things) will all be critical technologies for future smart cities. The research challenge is how to evolve beyond current technologies (e.g. OpenFlow) to support this complex multidomain (service providers and operators; interdependent infrastructures) heterogeneous multitechnology environment. The architecture must support service virtualization over these domains and technologies, and previous programmable network architectures such as DARPA Active Nets and the PSTN (public switched telephone network) IN (Intelligent Network) may provide some insight. Instru- mentation and management is critical, and must be designed into the architecture.

Platforms: A number of platforms will be necessary to support the architectures developed that go beyond existing OpenFlow and NFV capabilities for the smart city environment. This includes the development of scalable, highly dependable and resilient, high-performance SDXs (software designed exchanges), distributed SDN controllers, and measurement and instrumentation platforms. Interoperability standards will be needed that do not constrain capabilities, and that are in harmony with future IoT, 5G, and 802.11x wireless technologies and platforms, as well as with interdependent critical infrastructures such as smart grids and VANETs (vehicular ad hoc networks – that supplement network connectivity and are dependent on the network for control and autonomous behavior). Testbeds will be essential to research platform interconnection and interoperability.

Smart city services and applications: While it is difficult to predict future services, we will need plausible case studies to test proposed architectures and platforms. These include smart city situational awareness, energy monitoring for and across smart homes and buildings, and smart traffic control over mulitple modes (e.g. rail, mass transit, individual vehicles, bicycle, pedestrian), and disaster management. Sensing from smart buildings and vehicles will be critical to provide service provision. as well as energy management and conservation. Testbeds will also be essential to experiment with services and applications.

Control, management, security, resilience: The smart city environment will be significantly more complex than the current Internet (multi-level, multirealm policy and trust, multitechnology, interdependent critical infrastructures), with even greater privacy and dependability requirements that directly affect the well-being and lives of its inhabitants, ability to provide government ser- vices, and energy use and conservation. Research will be necessary into new mechanisms for the management and control of these complex environments, as well as to deliver needed security and resilience in the face of hostile attackers and large-scale disasters. Sensing and situational awareness from smart buildings, vehicles, and novel technologies including UAVs (unpiloted areal vehicles) will play a key role.

US-Korea Synergies

Smart city deployments: Korea has been a leader in Smart City deployments, e.g. Dongtan, Sejong, and Songdo. Smart city initiatives are beginning in the US as well, e.g. Kansas City and Columbus. Korea leads in the early collection of smart city data that could be exploited by US data analytics and network science expertise. One possibility is to explore the possibility of US-Korea Smart Sister Cities using US-Korea SDXs.

Network infrastructure and high-bandwidth access: Korea has a relatively dense popu- lation and is an early adopter of advanced networking technology, including LTE-Advanced and Gigabit/s residential fiber. The US has very significant low-density rural populations and small towns with a greater digital divide, in which high-bandwidth Internet access lags. Furthermore, in- frastructure deployment and economics differ. Solutions for the smart city will benefit by US-Korea collaboration to serve these different environments.

Testbeds, platforms, and SDXs: The US is a leader in programmable network testbeds, GENI, in particular, as well as cloud computing initiatives; Korea is a leader in physical infrastructure testbeds such as KREONET. Federating these testbeds across SDXs in the context of smart city research using the IoT has clear synergies. The incorporation of different platforms, instrumentation, and measurement technologies and expertise will be critical in international smart-city interoperation.

Cross-cultural opportunities: Differences in culture and society provide many benefits, in- cluding differing use, application, and service cases to test the applicability of proposed solutions, interaction of different governance models between the US and Korea, as well as educational and research exchanges via distance learning and student exchange visits.

Control, management, security, and resilience: Korea/US collaboration will advance the research in the interoperation and reconciliation of of differing network control, management, and security policies based on different service provider deployment models and economics. Further- more, collaboration on differing public safety policies, and differences in the structure and relative importance of critical infrastructures (e.g. rail vs. road), and differing threat models and disaster scenarios will help lead to generally applicable solutions in this area.
